40829578.review:
Bio Inc. Redemption is a fun little game that shares some similarities with Plague Inc. Evolved, in terms that you have to collect ressources (in this game it is biomass, in form of blood cells as a Good Doktor, or Viruses as a Bad Doktor) to find a cure against the diseases of your patients...or to make him even more sick so that the best doktors cant safe him anymore. 

You have the choice of playing either at the side of Death that tries to kill the subject...or at the side of Life and try to heal him. 

In the Side of Death you play as Doktor Ego, who has fallen totally to the believes of Gabbanism, in which he thinks that he is the center of the universe and everyone else only exists to entertain him. And since he works as a Doktor and the patients annoy him...he thinks that its better to heal you from all pain for ever, by headshotting you with a pistol, than by actual healing someone. As Dr. Ego you try to inflict viruses that affect certain body system to force them to collaps, like focussing on getting the lungs to collabs, so that even with intense help of the real doktors, the patient cant be safed. But because this mode is so activly, which means that you decide when to attack which systems, and the doktors have to work against it, this gamemode is becoming quickly very repettitive since you can do the exact same diseases over and over, since the doktors will of course not have a cure for heart-problems for example as long you dont infect the heart. So you can just infect the same systems in every game over and over again and you will most likely be successfull

The other side that you can play is the Side of Life, as a real Doktor who tries to safe the life of their patients. You play as Doktor NEW, a good-natured Doktor who cares about the well beeing of his patients and try to safe them together with his lovely wife, Dr. Mackintosh, by developing a cure to every disease that your patient has. Playing as NEW is much harder that playing as Dr. Ego, since you will have to play reactive. With every disease your patient will have certain amounds of symptoms of the disease, like coughing, mood swings, pain etc. and every symptom can be caused by many different diseases. So before you can develop cures to the diseases, you first have to find which disease did infect your patient, by selecting from many different tests that can determine the diseases. If your prognosis was correct you can start to develop cures to your diseases that will decrease the amound of harm that your patient will get every secound. But be quick, since Dr. Ego will not rest and infect your poor patient with more infections over time so you have to find the diseases as quickly as possible to safe your patient. 

I personally like the reactive playstyle of Dr. NEW way more, since you really have to react from situation to situation and really think about what disease your patient will have most likely based on the symptoms he has. It is way more stressful to play but also feels way more rewarding, when you try to safe your patient by last measures like a heart transplantation just to keep him a little while more alife, so that you can develop the cure in the last secound. 

Also you will safe a innocent person and not doom them to their death. 

So be a hero - be NEW

40814776.review:
Overview:
Bio Inc. Redemption is a resource-management strategy game that has the player either saving or killing patients with various diseases. As you play though the single player, different challenges and objectives grow more diverse and difficult, while the online mode offers a way to compete against your friends or strangers to either save a patient's life, or cause their unruly demise.

Gameplay:
Bio Inc. Redemption offers two distinct but similar ways of playing: life or death. In life, you are tasked with finding each disease that plagues a patient, and curing them of their ailments before they die. In death, the player is tasked with killing their patients by evolving diseases until their patient is overwhelmed. Players must harvest three different tiers of resources, and each style of play determines what kind of upgrades they can choose from. Harvesting resources is as easy as holding down the left mouse button until the resource is harvested, but the higher tiered resources disappear quickly, and these resources spawn randomly across all of the body’s systems.

During these campaigns, a patient’s vital signs are displayed in overall health, and other vital signs are broken up into the circulatory, respiratory, digestive, skeletal, nervous, renal, immune, and muscular system. All of the patient’s systems affect the overall health of a patient, and if one system fails, the rest of the systems begin to deteriorate. Once a patient’s symptoms and vitals reach a low enough point, they will visit a doctor routinely, and once a patient has a system in danger of failing, they will be rushed to the ER, and the efforts made to save the patient will increase, and it will make killing the patient more difficult.

While playing life, certain systems of a patient will deteriorate, so you must diagnose each disease that is affecting the body in order to treat it. You get general hints of what might be causing illnesses through symptom severity. Collected resources are used to perform tests to see if a patient has positive or negative reads for certain diseases. If tests come back positive for disease(s), then resources can be spent to treat those ailments, and both diagnosing and treating diseases take time. Once you cure your patient, you win, or you win when you have completed that level’s objective. You lose once your patient has reached 0% overall health.

On the flip side, playing death has you creating diseases, promoting unhealthy lifestyles, and cause medical hardships for a patient. Once you instill disease into a patient, you can cause greater harm by essentially upgrading these diseases from disease trees. Certain diseases and detriments can only be unlocked when you have met one or multiple prerequisites, such as having obesity or having certain diseases. You win when you kill your patient or complete the level’s objective, and you lose if your patient has been cured.

Each playstyle offers, as mentioned before, lifestyle changes, and resource investments that can help in the long run. For life, you can invest resources to slow down the deterioration of certain systems in a patient to give more time to cure them. You can also restore a system’s health up to a certain point with surgeries with some of the For death, you can invest in bad habits to boost the effectiveness of diseases in certain systems, increase the chance of developing random diseases, reducing the effectiveness of treatments, and more.

While the gameplay is simple, it tries to make up for it with its complex system of play. With thousands of possibilities and strategies, the replayability can be quite strong. Games are long, however, and this can either be a blessing or a curse to some. In addition, as you play and complete levels, you gain experience based on a few factors, and that experience goes to leveling up your player’s account. As you gain levels, you can select perks to help you in either campaign, and more player levels unlock more perk slots.

One of the biggest and obvious disparities between life and death gameplay is how straightforward the gameplay is. Death is a bit more obvious, and the gameplay seems more intuitive and requires less of a complex understanding in order to have fun and play effectively. Life, on the other hand, seems to be more of an educated guessing game. Although it isn’t the worst thing in the world, and it has its own strategy for playing, death felt much more rewarding and easier to grasp. In addition, the harder levels feel like they almost require perks. While it makes sense to have trouble beating hard level immediately, it felt more like the difficulty was designed to be combated only if you have certain perks rather than be a test of skill and strategy.

Game Design:
The game’s graphics are standard at best. They get the job done, but the awesome part is how each bodily system is designed. When you select a system, the internal workings of that system are displayed, and as a patient’s health deteriorates, afflicted systems begin to deteriorate as well. It was a neat touch that added to the experience.

That being said, the game’s animations get in the way of gameplay. Because resources spawn on a patient’s model, any time the model moves, the resources move with the model itself. It makes it difficult to collect resources during animations and makes harder levels artificially difficult. There are also blood animations that are distracting, but there is an option to turn these off. In addition, the game allows you to dress up patients as different characters, such as political figures, holiday mascots, and even gaming personalities, but these also end up being distracting and can hide resources accidentally. It is also recommended to avoid costumes unless for novel or comedic reasons.

The UI in Bio Inc. Redemption is straightforward and works quite well. The information can be a little overwhelming at times, but everything you need is unobstructed, and it will always be available for you at the a press of a button. You can also set custom keybindings to quickly swap between most sections for a better experience.

The music provided in this game is alright. The menu music is good, and the themes that play during life and death gameplay are alright. There is a frantic track that plays while a patient is in the ER, but it can be a bit grating, especially when a heart monitor is constantly beeping. The music does not loop perfectly, but it is a bit more forgivable in this case because there is not a huge gap between replays.

The game had a couple technical issues, and I had the game crash twice on me during multiplayer. Oddly enough, it never crashed during single player, but it made playing multiplayer a bit of a drag when it crashed. There was also a glitch in single player that did not allow me to see the symptoms of a patient. Other than these two problems, no other technical issues seem to be present.

Online:
Bio Inc. Redemption has a multiplayer aspect to it, and it consists of a ranked mode and a casual mode that you can use to play with your friends. Rankings are divided into overall rank, life rank, and death rank. While playing online, you can choose between the life, death, or a random side, and the matchmaking will pair you with the opposite choice. In multiplayer, you compete against your opponent to save or kill the same patient. It operates the same way as the single player mode, except there are no perks, and you are playing against another person in real time. Queues are long, however, and take anywhere from 3-5 minutes to find, but selecting random helps with the long wait. There is also an option to change what multiplayer mode to play as while in the lobby. Since there is only versus mode, this would imply that more multiplayer modes will be released eventually.

Score: 7.5/10

Read the full write-up here: https://grvaldez.weebly.com/bio-inc-redemption-review.html

I'd love to recommend this game. It's a lot of fun, but I can't recommend it in the state it was released. It clearly has had very little to no QA done on it.

The game crashes. A lot. To the point that it's nearly impossible to actually enjoy it. Most of the crashes appear to be due to a memory leak that some basic checking with valgrind or even just playtesting should have caught. If you leave the game open for an hour on the main menu, it will crash.

There's also tons of little things that never should have made it into a production release of a game. For example, the release announcement mentions that one of the things the developers have added due to community request is the ability to pick the gender of the patient. And yet they didn't bother to learn that it's spelled Jane *Doe*, not Do. And none of the pronouns used change based on the gender you pick. Also -- anorexia is not a female specific disease...

Hopefully the game gets fixed, I'd love to finish it if they ever patch it. But given that it made it to release with the sort of issues that even the most basic of QA should have caught, I don't have much hope.

40035393.review:
Ante mis ojos veo una persona saludable, su nombre es Julio Andrés, ciudadano honesto y estudioso, pero con muy malos hábitos alimenticios. Bio Inc. Redemption me pone a elegir, ¿quiero ser su héroe salvador y ayudar a curar los males que se avecinan sobre él?, o puedo ser el creador de muchas posibles enfermedades que se pueden desarrollar en dicho paciente. Como todos llevamos un doctor retorcido dentro, he escogido ser el artífice que desencadene muchos malos en su cuerpo.

Para ponerlo en otras palabras, en Bio Inc. Redemption, somos la cura o la enfermedad. Si decidimos ser ”Vida”, hemos de enfocarnos en curar a los pacientes, realizando exámenes para saber sus males, y recetarles medicamentos, tratamientos, o hasta trasplantes de órganos si es necesario. Si escogemos ser ”Muerte”, nuestro único objetivo es crear en nuestro desafortunado paciente una cantidad de males nunca antes vista, desde una bronquitis crónica, coágulos en la sangre, hasta uno que otro cáncer que le haga desmejorar su salud o perecer.

Todo esto se hace desde un HUD que al principio puede parecer colapsado, pero en realidad, a los pocos minutos nos acostumbramos. Al lado izquierdo de la pantalla se ven los distintos sistemas del cuerpo: circulatorio, respiratorio, digestivo, nervioso, renal, inmune y muscular; a estos podemos darles clic, para seleccionarles (ya veremos para que).

En el medio, vemos una silueta de cuerpo humano, la cual va a representar visualmente cada uno de los sistemas del lado izquierdo del menú. Esta visualización, muestra un modelado en tres dimensiones muy bonito, detallado y que permite ver en tiempo real que tan afectado esta alguna parte del cuerpo a según la enfermedad que padezca el individuo.

Por último, al lado derecho en el HUD, se encuentra información de los exámenes y tratamientos bajo los cuales el paciente está siendo sometido, y se pueden mirar algunos de los procesos en los cuales el individuo evoluciona o mejora.

Toda la información necesaria para jugar se encuentra en estos tres apartados que vamos a tener de primera mano en pantalla; por otro lado, pero igual de importante, tenemos el Bio Mapa. Este, muestra distintas maneras de afecta/mejorar la salud de nuestro pobre enfermo. Hay tres distintas opciones al elegir Muerte: Enfermedades, Factores de Riesgo, y Recuperación. Si elegimos Vida, tenemos: Diagnósticos, Estilos de Vida y Cuidado Intensivo.

En el tab de Enfermedades, se hallan decenas de males que afectan a cualquier ser humano. Si elegimos ser la Muerte, pues nos toca ponernos a escoger qué trastornos haremos que afecten al paciente, o, si somos Vida, usamos dicha lista de enfermedades para realizar exámenes y llevar a cabo pruebas que determinen el padecimiento de la persona.

Las enfermedades se desbloquean mediante Bio Puntos, estos se consiguen a lo largo de la partida mediante clics en el cuerpo humano que vemos en el centro de la pantalla, pequeños organismos representados como unas bolitas de color café (1 punto), azul (2 puntos), y verde (3 puntos) nos darán los medios necesarios para desencadenar las siete plagas o la cura definitiva según el bando que optamos tomar.

Los Factores de Riesgo son rasgos, o situaciones antes los cuales un individuo puede aumentar su probabilidad de sufrir una enfermedad (o empeorarla), llámense alcoholismo, ninfomanía, tabaquismo, sobrepeso, males hereditarios, o la inevitable vejez. Bio Inc. Redemption hace un gran trabajo desde el punto de vista “medico”, abarcando muchos escenarios, según los males que aquejen a la persona. En el otro lado de la barda, los Diagnósticos claramente funcionan para lograr dar con las enfermedades. Los Estilos de Vida, ponen a nuestro paciente a realizar cambios radicales en sus vidas, como hacer ejercicio, beber más agua, descansar mayores cantidades de tiempo, ir al gimnasio, etc.

La jugabilidad se centra en dar clicks, mediante los cuales interactuamos con las opciones que comentamos en los párrafos anteriores. Acumulando Bio Puntos, para enseguida gastarlos en enfermedades o exámenes médicos. En eso se centra y se resume Bio Inc. Redemption. Lo mejor de Bio Inc. Redemption es su apartado multijugador online, donde podemos jugar con algún amigo o persona aleatoria, siendo un experto galeno (Vida), o desatando el mal con virus y muchos otros padecimientos en nuestra victima (Muerte).

Técnicamente, Bio Inc. Redemption anda de lujo -tampoco es que necesite muchos recursos para correr, pero no tuvimos crasheos, o lag en las partidas que jugamos solos ni las que disputamos con nuestro colega Marco, donde lastimosamente, dimos muerte varias veces a un amigo en común que apreciamos mucho.

Visual y auditivamente pasable, Bio Inc. Redemption es un juego casual recomendado, donde podemos vivir segundos de apremio tratando de salvar una vida al borde de la muerte, o sentir en carne propia que tenemos el control de una vida humana -virtualmente; incluso podemos aprender un poco de medicina.

El título es creado por el desarrollador independiente Dry Gin Studios, y es la secuela del también llamativo Bio Inc – Biomedical Plague. De momento tiene un precio de $12.99 USD en la tienda digital de Valve.

39760712.review:
Un videojuego que combina la estrategia con la medicina, sumando a la experiencia de "matar al paciente" de la primera versión la nueva experiencia de "salvar al paciente", sin llegar a agobiarte con tecnicismos aunque si explicando lo suficiente cada síntoma y cada tratamiento.

Además de los modos principales, "Modo Vida" y "Modo Muerte", al estar aún en desarrollo, se están preparando novedades cada cierto tiempo, como una beta de multiugador y síntomas u opciones nuevas, como la Ruleta de las ETS.

Personalmente me considero aficionado a la medicina, y este juego me permite creerme Dr House, y aprender más sobre mi propio cuerpo sin sentirse como una enseñanza forzada del tipo "Uy mira qué cultural, la cultura es lo mejor, ¿verdad que sí?" La música ayuda bastante, recomiento el tema que suena cuando el paciente a salvar entra a Cuidados Intensivos.

Si estuviese en español sería perfecto, por lo demás como fan de los juegos de estrategia lo recomiendo mucho.

39663085.review: Это на столько анти-Гиппократично... В смысле, в этой игре Вы можете играть не только на стороне медицинской бригады, но и на стороне смерти развивающей болезни пациенту. Что бы пройти игру на 100%, Вам доведется поиграть за обе стороны. Разумеется, я решил начать с темной стороны, просто что бы завершить игру уже светлой (медицинской бригадой). Игра затягивающая, и с первых же минут становится ясно - сделана она на высшем уровне. С точки зрений геймдизайна, здесь нету к чему придраться. Иконки, текст, описание болезней и лечения - все великолепно выглядит, в том числе скроллинг списков. Эффекты и поведение пациента тоже привносит в игру некое разнообразие. Ну и конечно же система случайно генерирующая болезни, факторы риска и образ жизни - делает игру всякий раз не повторяющейся на предыдущую. Музыкальное сопровождение в игре меня порадовало. Саундтреки здесь динамические, и в зависимости от ситуаци, меняются. Когда пациента госпитализируют, спокойная мелодия резко меняется на эпичную до мурашек музыку, и это вынуждает Вас как игрока повысить свою концентрацию и принимать быстрые и взвешенные решения (поскольку при разрушении одной из систем организма, она за собой разрушает и другие, и времени на спасение пациента становится существенно меньше). Тот факт, что в этой игре огромное кол-во болезней, симптомов, методов диагностики и способов лечения - делает игру по истине оправдывающей жанр "Биомедицинский Симулятор". Играя в Bio Inc, страшно даже кашлять или сидеть в кресле с плохой осанкой) Мне пока не удалось опробовать бета-мультиплеер. Но я уверен, что играя с другом для Вас игра будет не менее захватывающей чем в режиме одиночной игры. На данный момент, можно играть друг против друга, но я верю что спустя какое-то время добавятся и другие режимы, в которых можно быть на одной стороне. На этом моя рецензия подходит к концу. Несомненно рекомендую. Тот редкий случай, когда проект в раннем доступе имеет весьма готовый внешний вид и положительные отзывы.

39613751.review:
Concrètement, le jeu est un Plague Inc. / Pandemic à l'échelle d'un individu au lieu d'être à l'échelle de la planète. Vous tentez de sauver une personne des assauts des pires pathologies, ou bien vous tentez de la tuer le plus dégueulassement possible.

La seconde partie, plus perverse, est assez jouissive et constitue le sel principal du jeu à mon sens.

Plusieurs niveaux de difficulté vous promettent un beau challenge mais une fois les mécaniques maîtrisées, le jeu devient plus du scoring plus qu'autre chose.

La durée de vie parâit donc limitée et certaines fonctionnalités demandent à être améliorées : choix du sexe du patient, plus de cohérence entre les pathologies et symptômes (diarrhée et constipation en même temps c'est pas très très réaliste), instauration de réels scénarios...

Il faut donc rester mesuré : le jeu est bon, mais manque de contenu pour son prix. Ce n'est cependant qu'une EA et les devs ont l'air de bien suivre. Je conseille donc le jeu aux amateurs du genre une fois ces réserves-là en tête.
